awd_titl_txt: Network for Computational Nanotechnology Cyber Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
Network for Computational Nanotechnology (NCN) was founded in 2002 to advance nanoscience toward nanotechnology via online simulations on nanoHUB.org. Not only has nanoHUB become the first broadly successful, scientific end-to-end cloud computing environment, but it also has evolved well beyond online simulation. Annually, nanoHUB provides a library of 3,000 learning resources to 195,000 users worldwide. Its 232 simulation tools, free from the limitations of running software locally, are used in the cloud by over 10,800 annually. Its impact is demonstrated by 720+ citations to nanoHUB in the scientific literature with over 4,807 secondary citations, yielding an h-index of 31, and by a median time from publication of a research simulation program to classroom use of less than 6 months. Cumulatively, over 14,000 students in over 760 formal classes in over 100 institutions have used nanoHUB simulations. 

Despite a decade of transformational success for a broad nanotechnology research and education community, significant gaps remain as work is still performed by isolated individuals and small groups. This fragmentation by specialty hinders tool and data sharing across knowledge domains. Nano areas such as bio, photonics, and materials are only beginning to use nanoHUB while manufacturing, informatics, environmental-health-and-safety are to date not even represented on nanoHUB. The NCN Cyber Platform proposes to address these gaps through efforts in three strategic goals to: 1) accelerate research by transforming nanoscience to nanotechnology through the integration of simulation with experimentation; 2) inspire and educate the next-generation nanoscience and nanotechnology workforce; and 3) grow the nanoHUB society that uses and shares nanoHUB content. Five cross-cutting thrust areas focus on the cyberinfrastructure (CI) and social dynamics of the nanoHUB virtual society: CI innovation; content stewardship and node engagement; education research and precollege/college and lifelong learning; outreach, diversity, and marketing; and CI operations. The 10-year NCN nanoHUB Cyber Platform vision is that nanoHUB will be the online nano society that researchers, practitioners, educators and students depend on day-to-day while simultaneously immersed in professional practice and computational resources for a multidisciplinary culture of innovation grounded in cloud services-enabled workflows.

Intellectual Merit: The NCN nanoHUB strategic plan will answer two fundamental challenges to the next-generation nanoHUB experience: 1) development of technologies that enable simple management and publication of scientific data (experimental and simulation) without additional complex steps: and 2) the establishment of a value system that fosters publication of data, tools, and lectures similar to today's rewards for journal publications. CI innovation, developed through the leading HUBzero platform as well as in cooperation with other CI efforts, will enable new connection points for research, education, and commercialization, expanded platform tool features to help users exchange and publish data; combined data and tools for verification, validation, and engineering activities; and increase immersive and pervasive features. Through partnerships with professional societies and commercial publishers, nanoHUB will change how researchers publish their simulation results through novel interactive journals that reflect a user's workflow, link directly back to their data, and make the work reproducible. This value system will drive new content toward nanoHUB, obviating the need for content generation to be monetarily supported by NCN. Through partnerships with the three new NCN content nodes and other NSF-funded nano efforts, NCN will continue to foster content creation to demonstrate value to the authors and will prototype, test, and host the proposed new technologies for broad usage.

Broader Impacts: NCN has developed processes that enabled researchers to rapidly deploy their research codes and innovative tutorials and classes on nanoHUB. To date, these processes harvested research and educational results from 890 contributors world-wide. Expansion into new areas of nano research and education, including pre-college education, represent a huge growth potential for nanoHUB that goes beyond simulation to embracing data management, search, and exploration. Focus on diversity will continue to be an integral part of NCN's outreach program, in particular through focused workshops and new initiatives such as EPICS High. The NCN-pioneered HUBzero already powers 40 HUBs at 12 institutions, serving a broad range of science and engineering disciplines and commercialization. Through impact assessment and continual contributions to HUBzero software stack releases, nanoHUB will continue to drive impact beyond its nano society into other disciplines and institutions.

por.por_cntn:
Since launching in 2002, nanoHUB has become an invaluable resource for educators, students, and researchers globally. As one of the most successful science gateways funded by the NSF, nanoHUB?s open, accessible, and scalable infrastructure has had a profound impact on education and research. Originally, nanoHUB aimed to provide computational nano scientists with a way to make advanced modeling and simulation tools accessible to experimentalists, educators, students, and researchers in related domains.Over the last two decades, nanoHUB has enabled three paradigm shifts: 1) research simulation tool use in education, 2) cloud-based simulation tools used in research, and 3) new types of publications (digital assets such as tools and compact models).


Overcoming fundamental challenges
In the late 1990s, portals were introduced to broadly enable the sharing of computational science software and data. However, early portals were difficult to use, requiring expert knowledge, resulting in a poor user-experience. They delivered static outputs that were often hard to analyze. The usability of these tools was a significant barrier, as they were not designed for non-experts.To address this, nanoHUB adopted a different approach by developing tools that were easy to use, interactive, and able to run many virtual experiments in the same numerical experiment. nanoHUB developed a Graphical User Interface (GUI) approach to enable computational scientists and students to quickly wrap complex codes into simplified user experiences. "Rappture" interfaces were fully interactive from simulation setup, execution, and result comparisons. The Rappture system was easily adopted by undergraduate summer students who had a fully functional tool publication by the end of a summer.The fully interactive tools were delivered through a novel virtual remote desktop middleware system that could run in any browser. By 2005, nanoHUB had essentially created the first end-to-end user cloud which was running interactive scientific apps. Over time, nanoHUB has grown to host over 850 apps, which have been used by over 205,000 simulation users.

Use of research tools in education

Initially, there were doubts about whether research-based apps would be adopted in formal education. However, through early anecdotal evidence, it became clear that faculty and students were successfully integrating nanoHUB tools in their structured university programs. Through data analysis, we clustered similar user behavior, location, and registration information. By 2024, using this clustering analysis, we identified around 100,000+ users as students and faculty at over 404 validated institutions in over 4,200 courses. Worldwide our over 300,000 registered users represent over 81,000 institutions!In addition to modeling and simulation tools, nanoHUB offers over 7,000 other content items providing educational scaffolding around these tools.nanoHUB has changed the paradigm of immersive hands-on education through online modeling and simulation and has changed the expectations and approaches to the field of nanotechnology.Commercial Electronic Design Automation (EDA) tools, which vendors were initially reluctant to move to the cloud, are now part of nanoHUB?s offerings. As a result, instructors can use these tools without the hassle of managing local software installations. Instructors like Dragica Vasileska from Arizona State University have praised nanoHUB for making simulation tools more accessible to their students.We?ve effectively lowered barriers to access to these powerful tools that are otherwise not available to many universities. This includes the use of nanoHUB in 43% of U.S. technical universities and 56% of all technical minority serving institutions thus far.

Cloud-enabled tools for research!

Though early reviewers doubted the use of nanoHUB tools in research, the platform has become indispensable for researchers. By tracking academic citations of nanoHUB?s tools, it became evident that the research enabled by nanoHUB was not only impactful but also getting significant recognition in the scientific community. By 2024, nanoHUB had been cited in over 2,900 research papers which have over 84,000 secondary Great citations resulting in an h-index of 135. These citations, including those from experimentalists, industry, and educational research, show that nanoHUB has facilitated impactful research across various fields.

A new type of publication
In 2005, nanoHUB began assigning Digital Object Identifiers (DOIs) to published tools. This was a novel concept at the time.In 2016 Thompson-Reuters which hosts the Web-of-Science approached nanoHUB to create the first listings of digital assets and publications. By 2017, nanoHUB tools were officially listed as publications in the Web of Science, and soon after in Google Scholar. This recognition allows authors to include these tools in their academic CVs, further validating their importance in research.In conclusion, nanoHUB?s impact on education and research is profound. Through the open-access platform, it has revolutionized STEM education by providing interactive tools and simulations that are freely accessible to students and educators worldwide. Additionally, by enabling cloud-based research tools and recognizing digital assets as formal publications, nanoHUB has shaped the future of scientific research. The platform?s impact continues to grow with the development of Chipshub, making nanoHUB an indispensable resource.
